page.title: 06INTERVIEWS WITH O.A.P.S
page.content: MRS.MUSSON AND MR.EVANS ARE BOTH WELL-KNOWN AND ESTABLISHED CHARACTERS IN DIDCOT. BEFORE THE 1970S, DIDCOT WAS NOT A TOWN BUT TWO VILLAGES, NORTHBOURNE AND DIDCOT. DURING THE NINETEENTH CENTURY THE TOWN GREW UP TO SERVICE THE NEW RAILWAY; THE ARMY BARRACKS AND HARWELL A.E.R.E. ALSO INCREASED DIDCOT'S POPULATION AND EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES. MR.EVANS, HOWEVER, DISAPPROVES OF THE TOWN'S EXPANSION. DIDCOT, HE FEELS, HAS LOST ITS CLOSE-KNIT COMMUNITY, MANY OF THE INHABITANTS NOT HAVING BEEN BORN THERE. MRS.MUSSON HAS NOTED THE INCREASING ISOLATION OF WEST DIDCOT FROM THE REST OF THE TOWN ALTHOUGH IT HAS SOME WIDELY-USED AMENITIES SUCH AS THE HEALTH CENTRE AND THE LADYGROVE DAY CENTRE. MORE GARDENS, ANOTHER DAY CENTRE, BETTER TRAVEL FACILITIES NEEDED
